Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Collaborative Research: Role of Bristled Wings for Flying and Swimming at Low Reynolds Numbers

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1512071(Santhanakrishnan) & 1511427(Miller)

The focus of the proposed project is to explore the fluid dynamic principles that enable small insects to generate lift and produce thrust. When the wings of small insects clap together during the flapping motion and then fling apart, there is the expectation that flight would not be efficient, but it is. Resolving this paradox can have a significant scientific and technological impact, because we could also design machinery that takes advantage of such phenomena like small robotic vehicles that move across fluid-air interfaces.

The proposal is focused on the understanding of the phenomena involved when bristled wings, like those of small insects generate lift. Although the aerodynamic principles of insect flight at the scale of fruit flies and above are reasonably well understood, the fluid dynamic mechanisms that enable very tiny insects to generate lift or thrust remain unclear. When the wings clap together at the end of the upstroke of the flapping motion and fling apart at the start of the downstroke, there are novel phenomena that take place. The fundamental investigation in this work will be focused on a particularly intriguing paradox: why is there a noted biological preference in almost all tiny insects to employ interacting bristled wings under highly viscous conditions that would require large forces to peel the wings apart? It is proposed to develop 3D poroelastic models to study locomotion using bristled appendages. Two types of insects will be examined (thrips and parasitoid wasps), which are capable of flying in air and swimming in water. The experiments in this proposal will also use robotic wing-wing interaction platforms with dynamically scaled bristled wing models informed by high-speed videos of tiny insects. Wing design and kinematics for flapping propulsion at low Re will be identified through numerical simulations of experimentally validated poroelastic wing models implemented in an immersed boundary method framework. Graduate and undergraduate student involvement in the research is proposed. Minority student participation will be pursued through the Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) program at both institutions. Outreach activities for high school students and teachers participating in the Oklahoma State University National Lab Day annual event are also described.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

The primary goal of this project was to reveal the aerodynamics of the smallest flying insects. Throughout the project, we used a three-pronged approach that included 1) kinematic measurements taken from actual flying insects, 2) force and flow field measurements taken from dynamically scaled physical models of flapping wings, and 3) computational models of flapping wings. Our main results were that 1) dimensionless drag increased as Reynolds number decreased, 2) flight became less efficient for smaller insects, 3) tiny insects could produce more lift by clapping their wings together and flinging them apart, and 4) the bristles characteristic of most tiny insect wings serve to enhance aerodynamic efficiency by lowering drag while maintaining lift. Overall, these observations suggest that there are drastic differences between the aerodynamics of flight at the scale of the smallest flying insects and of larger insects such as fruit flies and moths. This project resulted in at least 10 publications in interdisciplinary journals including the Journal of Experimental Biology, Royal Society Interface, Fluids and Biomimetics and Bioinspiration.

 

This work combines computational, mathematical, and experimental tools to ultimately answer some of questions posed in one of the five grand challenges in organismal biology: Integrating living and physical systems. Bristled appendages that operate at Reynolds numbers near unity have evolved repeatedly in many contexts. Bristled arrays are common tools for a variety of tasks involving fluid-structure interactions, including feeding, swimming, and flying. At this scale, bristled arrays typically act as a solid surface, but there may be moments of higher velocity, interactions with surfaces, or increased spacing between bristles such that the arrays act as leaky rakes. Animals have creative ways of taking advantage of this transition. For example, copepods, small marine crustaceans, will slowly open their bristled feeding appendages to pull in water, and then quickly slap the appendages together to capture plankton between the bristles. Understanding the complicated fluid dynamics of interacting bristled appendages will likely provide insights into many biological processes as diverse as sniffing and swimming.

 

Broader Impacts:

The methods and tools developed for this project are freely available online and should find immediate use in a variety of biofluids applications. We have developed new tutorials and functionality for a parallel and adaptive implementation of the immersed boundary method (IBAMR) with Boyce Griffith. We have also developed 2D MATLAB and Python codes for use in undergraduate research, courses, and for smaller scale research projects. Three graduate students and six undergraduates were trained at the intersection of fluid dynamics, applied mathematics, and biomechanics.

 

The research conducted here was integrated into Miller's graduate courses and first year seminar on "Simulated Life". In the graduate courses, Miller focused on the use of IBAMR to solve biological fluid-structure interaction problems with examples coming from this research. Another important aspect of these activities was to teach practical skills for scientific computation. The first year seminar was focused on the development of semester long projects that used experimental and computational fluid dynamics to understand how organisms interact with fluids. Miller participated in two Faculty Learning Communities to enhance the impact of the above activities on student learning. This included participation in the Finish Line Project, which targets first generation college students, and the Makerspace Faculty Learning Community in which faculty partner with Makerspace staff to develop hands-on making modules.
